question.chain_of_thought: The algorithm is failing due to a special characteristic of a tensor. The successful execution of `torch.linalg.svdvals` indicates that the issue is related to singular value decomposition (SVD) of the tensor.
question.question: What special characteristic of the tensor is causing the algorithm to fail, and why is the successful execution of `torch.linalg.svdvals` relevant in this context?
question.answer: The special characteristic of the tensor causing the algorithm to fail is related to singular value decomposition (SVD). The successful execution of `torch.linalg.svdvals` indicates that the tensor may have properties that are suitable for SVD and can be decomposed successfully using this method.

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: INTERNAL ASSERT FAILED at "/opt/conda/conda-bld/pytorch_1634272068185/work/aten/src/ATen/native/LinearAlgebraUtils.h":244
username_0: ## üêõ Bug

Calling `torch.linalg.svd` on a large float64 tensor on the CPU (size 90k x ~34k) leads to this error. `torch.linalg.eigh` on `tensor.T@tensor` seg faults.
## To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. I don't know. I have a large tensor of type float64. Calling `torch.linalg.svd`on it produces this error.

```
Intel MKL ERROR: Parameter 12 was incorrect on entry to DGESDD.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
RuntimeError                              Traceback (most recent call last)
/tmp/ipykernel_3300/2679862595.py in <module>
----> 1 torch.linalg.svd(tensor)

RuntimeError: falseINTERNAL ASSERT FAILED at "/opt/conda/conda-bld/pytorch_1634272068185/work/aten/src/ATen/native/LinearAlgebraUtils.h":244, please report a bug to PyTorch. svd_cpu: Argument 12 has illegal value. Most certainly there is a bug in the implementation calling the backend library.
```
## Expected behavior

<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->

## Environment

Please copy and paste the output from our
[environment collection script](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pytorch/pytorch/master/torch/utils/collect_env.py)
(or fill out the checklist below manually).

You can get the script and run it with:
```
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pytorch/pytorch/master/torch/utils/collect_env.py
# For security purposes, please check the contents of collect_env.py before running it.
python collect_env.py
```

 - PyTorch Version (e.g., 1.0): '1.10.0'
 - OS (e.g., Linux): Linux
 - How you installed PyTorch (`conda`, `pip`, source): conda
 - Build command you used (if compiling from source):
 - Python version: 3.9.5
 - CUDA/cuDNN version:
 - GPU models and configuration:On the CPU
 - Any other relevant information:

## Additional context
`torch.linalg.eigh` on `tensor.T@tensor` seg faults.
<issue_comment>username_0: I have been trying to figure out what is special about this tensor that is causing the algorithm to fail.

I note that `torch.linalg.svdvals` is successful.
<issue_comment>username_0: Ok, I am now able to replicate this problem using just `torch.rand` and `torch.linalg.svd`.

The following fails:
```
x = torch.rand(30000,30000)
u,s,v = torch.linalg.svd(x)
```
<issue_comment>username_1: Thank you for the tiny repro! I can reproduce in master. cc @username_2
<issue_comment>username_2: The problem is related to https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/51720.

The optimal workspace size for the input of this size is `2.70021e+09` which doesn't fit into `int` type. In PyTorch, we use a 32-bit interface to backend linear algebra libraries.
We can "fix" the internal assert with this patch
```
diff --git a/aten/src/ATen/native/BatchLinearAlgebra.cpp b/aten/src/ATen/native/BatchLinearAlgebra.cpp
index 853f5c2cbe..8902958d98 100644
--- a/aten/src/ATen/native/BatchLinearAlgebra.cpp
+++ b/aten/src/ATen/native/BatchLinearAlgebra.cpp
@@ -2984,7 +2984,9 @@ static void apply_svd(Tensor& self, Tensor& U, Tensor& S, Tensor& VT,
   int lwork = -1;
   scalar_t wkopt;
   lapackSvd<scalar_t, value_t>(jobz, m, n, self_data, lda, S_data, U_data, lda, VT_data, ldvt, &wkopt, lwork, rwork_data, iwork_data, &info);
-  lwork = std::max<int>(1, real_impl<scalar_t, value_t>(wkopt));
+  TORCH_CHECK(
+      (real_impl<scalar_t, value_t>(wkopt)) < INT_MAX,
+      "svd: The optimal workspace size is larger than allowed by 32-bit interface to backend math library.");
   Tensor work = at::empty({lwork}, self.options());
   auto work_data = work.data_ptr<scalar_t>();
```
The issue is likely there for other functions as well and we could include checks of the values before casting them to int.
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_2 will there be any way around this in the future for large SVDs? Or is there an upper size limit due to the 32bit interface?
<issue_comment>username_2: Unfortunately, there is no workaround available.
From the MKL documentation the workspace size (`lwork`) can be computed using these guidelines:
```
For real flavors:

If jobz = 'N', lwork ‚â• 3*min(m, n) + max (max(m,n), 6*min(m, n));

If jobz = 'O', lwork ‚â• 3*(min(m, n))2 + max (max(m, n), 5*(min(m, n))2 + 4*min(m, n));

If jobz = 'S' or 'A', lwork ‚â• 3*(min(m, n))2 + max (max(m, n), 4*(min(m, n))2 + 4*min(m, n))

For complex flavors:

If jobz = 'N', lwork ‚â• 2*min(m, n) + max(m, n);

If jobz = 'O', lwork ‚â• 2*(min(m, n))2 + max(m, n) + 2*min(m, n);

If jobz = 'S' or 'A', lwork ‚â• (min(m, n))2 + max(m, n) + 2*min(m, n);
```
`lwork` must be smaller than `2147483647` (maximum `int`) in order to not hit the limitation of the 32-bit interface.
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_2 Any clue as to why `svdvals` and `eigvalsh` work?
<issue_comment>username_1: For what is worth, `svdvals` and `eigvalsh` may work in master when the input does not require gradients, as we do not compute the `U` and the `Vh` in those cases, so the working space needed is less than for the full SVD / eigendecomposition.

Title: getDerivedStateFrom{Props,Catch} should update updateQueue.baseState username_0: Based on a bug found in UFI2. There have been several bugs related to the update queue (and specifically baseState) recently, so I'm going to follow-up with some refactoring to clean it up. This is a quick fix so we can ship a patch release. username_1: This is hard to follow for me. What is your mental model for when it's safe and/or necessary to mutate `baseState`? How does this relate to `processUpdateQueue` that also mutates it? username_1: In particular I'm worried that a low-pri update can mutate `baseState` and then get interrupted. What guarantees we'll "disregard" that state-from-props next time we process a high pri update? username_0: We mutate `baseState` whenever we process the update queue. It represents the state before any of the updates in the queue are applied. It's different from `memoizedState` whenever we process an update but keep it in the queue. This happens when there are lower priority updates than what we're currently rendering, because we skip the low ones and come back to them later ‚Äî i.e. it's what makes this work: ![react explainer slides 004](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3624098/38271779-3720625c-373c-11e8-93a6-7a30e00d02f3.png) My mental model for `getDerivedStateFromProps` is a `setState` inside render, at the same priority as what we're currently rendering: ```js render() { this.setState((previousState, previousProps) => { if (previousProps !== this.props) { return getDerivedStateFromProps(this.props, previousState); } return null; }); } ``` If we actually implemented it this way, then `processUpdateQueue` would have taken care of updating `baseState` and this bug probably wouldn't have happened. We decided not to use the `updateQueue` to implement `getDerivedStateFromProps` because we wanted to avoid adding updates to the current queue, which shares a persistent structure. I thought it would be more elegant. But this bug indicates that it's more complicated than we thought, and we should reconsider. This is one of the things I will address in my follow-up PR. username_2: But the `nextState` prop passed to `componentWillUpdate` would have been incorrect. username_0: @username_2 What's a `componentWillUpdate`? username_3: Hi @username_0 I just wanted to point out that my getDerivedStateFromProps() _stopped working_ in my React 16.3.0., but as soon as I updated it to **16.3.1.**, it _started working again_. Thanks. However, my **forceUpdate** -inside getDerivedStateFromProps()- stopped working. Maybe it's related? username_1: `this.forceUpdate` (an instance method) is not supposed to work inside `getDerivedStateFromProps` (a static method). Why are you trying to use it? `getDerivedStateFromProps()` should be pure and have no side effects. username_3: @username_1 Before, I just had some logic that used forceUpdate() inside componentWillReceiveProps(). Particularly, I used it in a Google Maps component. As the map receives dropdown values, I wanted to show/hide InfoWindows for particular markers. Anyhow, since React is preparing ground for async an such, will refactor it as per your comment. Thanks again. username_3: I agree, very hard coded. This is what I had before for showing/hiding InfoWindows for current on-screen markers, you can see the `forceUpdate()` thrown in there. ``` if (newProps.dropFiscValue !== this.props.dropFiscValue) { const obj1 = {}; //=> Markers, InfoWindows upon Dropdown Fiscalizacion Value obj1.markersFisc = {}; obj1.iWsFisc = {}; obj1.iWVisibleFisc = {}; fisc_data.map((marker, index) => { // mapping over √Årea Inversiones data if (newProps.dropFiscValue === marker.empresa_responsable2) { const index2 = 'marker' + index.toString(); // id for Markers const markerFisc = {}; const index3 = 'marker' + index.toString() + 'IW'; // id for infoWindows const iWFisc = {}; const index4 = 'marker' + index.toString() + 'IW' + 'IsVisible'; // id for infoWindows State const iWState = {}; iWState[index4] = false; iWFisc[index3] = ( ' + marker.nombre_del_proyecto + '
' + '' + marker.empresa_responsable + '

question.chain_of_thought: The build failure was caused by the linker's inability to access the specified CUDA input file, resulting in the fatal error LNK1181. This explanation directly addresses the specific error message and its impact on the build process.
question.question: What caused the build failure in the provided text chunk related to linking CUDA files?
question.answer: The build failure occurred because the linker was unable to open the input file "C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v10.0\lib\x64.obj", leading to fatal error LNK1181.

set CUDNN_INCLUDE_DIR=

```

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Concurrent Mode and UseSubscription with RxJS "lose" updates 
username_0: <!--
  Note: if the issue is about documentation or the website, please file it at:
  https://github.com/reactjs/reactjs.org/issues/new
-->

**Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?**
**Bug** - I think? 

**What is the current behavior?**

In Concurrent Mode, it appears that if a render is interrupted, if a component is using `useSubscription` the interrupted update is lost, which leads to "tearing" 

The following codesandbox uses `useSubscription` with a RxJS `BehaviorSubject`, mimicking the example from here: https://www.npmjs.com/package/use-subscription#subscribing-to-observables 

In the sandbox, clicking on the "Increment Remote Count" button triggers the RxJs `BehaviorSubject` to increment. This is done outside of the React event handler (ie: via `window.addEventLIstener` and so the updates are not batched together. The update to render the numbers is artificially slowed down. 

If you click the "Increment Remote Count" button multiple times, the update works as expected. 

If you interrupt the update, via clicking the "increment local count" 


So the Steps to reproduce look like: 
1. Click the "Increment Remote Count" button once
2. Before the update is committed to the DOM, click the "Increment Local Count" update. 
3. The first update is "lost" ie; the output looks like: 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/787007/68468141-27255f80-0263-11ea-9afb-07964e21d9d9.png)


**If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce and if possible a minimal demo of the problem. Your bug will get fixed much faster if we can run your code and it doesn't have dependencies other than React. Paste the link to your JSFiddle (https://jsfiddle.net/Luktwrdm/) or CodeSandbox (https://codesandbox.io/s/new) example below:**

https://jwenc.csb.app/ \ https://codesandbox.io/s/usesubscriptionconcurrentlosingupdates-jwenc 

**What is the expected behavior?**

I'd expect there to be a commit as the above screenshot, but I'd then expect there to be a follow-up commit that restores the consistency. In other words, I'd expect in the above picture for everything to be `1` 

**Which versions of React, and which browser / OS are affected by this issue? Did this work in previous versions of React?**

`0.0.0-experimental-f6b8d31a7`


I'd be willing to try to take a stab at writing a React test for this, if needed?

question.chain_of_thought: The text mentions a potential issue with C++ extensions in the context of global visibility of symbols from libtorch_python. It suggests that if the symbols are not globally visible in the current process, the C++ extensions would fail to load at runtime even though they compile successfully. The question should probe further into the reason behind this behavior and how global visibility affects the loading of C++ extensions in this scenario.
question.question: Why would C++ extensions fail to load at runtime if the symbols from libtorch_python are not globally visible?
question.answer: C++ extensions would fail to load at runtime if the symbols from libtorch_python are not globally visible because the extensions require these symbols to have global visibility in the current process for successful loading. Without global visibility, the extensions are unable to access the necessary symbols during runtime, leading to loading failures despite compiling without any issues.

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: [RFC] Speed up python function and arg serialization in RPC APIs
username_0: ## üöÄ Feature
In our current RPC APIs (rpc_sync, async, rpc.remote), we first serialize (pickle) the function, argument, and kwargs being sent to the destination worker, and pass this serialized representation as a string in C++ to construct our notion of a `SerializedPyObj`. This is done so that we can send these bytes across the network and reconstruct the needed information on the remote end.

We have noticed some slowness in this python serialization, namely in use cases with a large number of remote trainers being set up as an RRef on a master/parameter server node. In setups like these, the following pattern is quite common:

```
# On parameter server
model = create_model(...)
for trainer_name in trainers:
    trainer_rref = rpc.remote(
        _setup_model_on_trainer,
        model,
        ...additional arguments, expensive to serialize
    )
```

Note that in the loop while the dst worker is different, the function and arguments being serialized are the same. This may mean that caching the serialized representation from call to call could be useful, speeding up the end to end latency. For speeding up individual calls, we can look into parallelizing the serialization, which will be more complex than simple caching as the parallelization would have to be implemented in the C++ layer.

## Motivation
In some training workloads, we have noticed serialization taking up a large portion of time when initializing the setup discussed above. Since many of these workloads follow the pattern above, caching/parallelization should be a good candidate to speed this up. 

## Pitch
Implement caching similar to the demo here: and evaluate its impact on the above described workloads. If parallelization across arguments in individual calls also sounds like it makes sense and is likely to result in a speedup, we can discuss a concrete implementation plan to move the pickling into C++ to take advantage of multiple cores.
<issue_comment>username_1: From the demo PR, looks like the args can contain a lot of small tensors. If that's the common case, RDMA in TensorPipe won't be sufficient. cc @username_2 and @beauby  for this use case. 

A follow-up question is in which layer we should put this caching/serialization logic? Probably not in TensorPipe to avoid over-complicating the comm layer. Two other options are in RPC or layers on top of RPC (e.g., applications, or helpers). Will it work if we provide a new decorator for RPC functions? E.g.:

```python
@rpc.functions.enable_caching
def my_function_to_cache(*args):
    pass
```
<issue_comment>username_2: Are you sure this is really feasible? I thought pickling requires holding the GIL, which would mean that even if it's done in C++ it cannot be done in parallel by multiple threads. Unless you were talking about TorchScript pickling, but as I said above that should already be faster, without any changes required in RPC, right?
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_2 True, after some more thought I agree moving pickling into C++ won't likely give us too much since we would need to immediately grab the GIL. TorchScript in general is our recommendation for improved performance and if this code were indeed TorchScripted, it would go through TS pickling, but some use cases may not be able to fully TorchScript their training loop. I think we can probably still proceed with the caching portion of this RFC, though.
<issue_comment>username_0: Sorry for the late reply, but we are actually trying to cache the results of pickling (python) args and functions themselves, not the actual result of the function. The idea is that many trainers issue the same RPCs and do (potentially) expensive pickling, when we could just be returning a cached result. Caching for application functions is tricky due to issues like idempotency and would probably be best handled by the user app (or we can provide the decorator as you mentioned).
<issue_comment>username_2: One issue with caching the pickled data is mutability. The application might know that the data won't change between two calls, but PyTorch doesn't and thus it would have to check, which could potentially be as slow as just pickling again.

I wonder if, as a start, we could fix this in the application: the user could _explicitly_ pickle what it wants to send over, obtain `bytes` objects for it, send those `bytes` as arguments of the RPC call, and have the remote function unpickle them back. This might be easier said than done, since if the values contain tensors it could get tricky. 

Maybe we should first try a few variations of these potential solutions in the application, and thus validate their correctness, usability and performance, before considering "upstreaming" the best one into PyTorch?
source.text: @username_2 True, after some more thought I agree moving pickling into C++ won't likely give us too much since we would need to immediately grab the GIL. TorchScript in general is our recommendation for improved performance and if this code were indeed TorchScripted, it would go through TS pickling, but some use cases may not be able to fully TorchScript their training loop. I think we can probably still proceed with the caching portion of this RFC, though.

Title: getDerivedStateFrom{Props,Catch} should update updateQueue.baseState username_0: Based on a bug found in UFI2. There have been several bugs related to the update queue (and specifically baseState) recently, so I'm going to follow-up with some refactoring to clean it up. This is a quick fix so we can ship a patch release. username_1: This is hard to follow for me. What is your mental model for when it's safe and/or necessary to mutate `baseState`? How does this relate to `processUpdateQueue` that also mutates it? username_1: In particular I'm worried that a low-pri update can mutate `baseState` and then get interrupted. What guarantees we'll "disregard" that state-from-props next time we process a high pri update? username_0: We mutate `baseState` whenever we process the update queue. It represents the state before any of the updates in the queue are applied. It's different from `memoizedState` whenever we process an update but keep it in the queue. This happens when there are lower priority updates than what we're currently rendering, because we skip the low ones and come back to them later ‚Äî i.e. it's what makes this work: ![react explainer slides 004](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3624098/38271779-3720625c-373c-11e8-93a6-7a30e00d02f3.png) My mental model for `getDerivedStateFromProps` is a `setState` inside render, at the same priority as what we're currently rendering: ```js render() { this.setState((previousState, previousProps) => { if (previousProps !== this.props) { return getDerivedStateFromProps(this.props, previousState); } return null; }); } ``` If we actually implemented it this way, then `processUpdateQueue` would have taken care of updating `baseState` and this bug probably wouldn't have happened. We decided not to use the `updateQueue` to implement `getDerivedStateFromProps` because we wanted to avoid adding updates to the current queue, which shares a persistent structure. I thought it would be more elegant. But this bug indicates that it's more complicated than we thought, and we should reconsider. This is one of the things I will address in my follow-up PR. username_2: But the `nextState` prop passed to `componentWillUpdate` would have been incorrect. username_0: @username_2 What's a `componentWillUpdate`? username_3: Hi @username_0 I just wanted to point out that my getDerivedStateFromProps() _stopped working_ in my React 16.3.0., but as soon as I updated it to **16.3.1.**, it _started working again_. Thanks. However, my **forceUpdate** -inside getDerivedStateFromProps()- stopped working. Maybe it's related? username_1: `this.forceUpdate` (an instance method) is not supposed to work inside `getDerivedStateFromProps` (a static method). Why are you trying to use it? `getDerivedStateFromProps()` should be pure and have no side effects. username_3: @username_1 Before, I just had some logic that used forceUpdate() inside componentWillReceiveProps(). Particularly, I used it in a Google Maps component. As the map receives dropdown values, I wanted to show/hide InfoWindows for particular markers. Anyhow, since React is preparing ground for async an such, will refactor it as per your comment. Thanks again. username_3: I agree, very hard coded. This is what I had before for showing/hiding InfoWindows for current on-screen markers, you can see the `forceUpdate()` thrown in there. ``` if (newProps.dropFiscValue !== this.props.dropFiscValue) { const obj1 = {}; //=> Markers, InfoWindows upon Dropdown Fiscalizacion Value obj1.markersFisc = {}; obj1.iWsFisc = {}; obj1.iWVisibleFisc = {}; fisc_data.map((marker, index) => { // mapping over √Årea Inversiones data if (newProps.dropFiscValue === marker.empresa_responsable2) { const index2 = 'marker' + index.toString(); // id for Markers const markerFisc = {}; const index3 = 'marker' + index.toString() + 'IW'; // id for infoWindows const iWFisc = {}; const index4 = 'marker' + index.toString() + 'IW' + 'IsVisible'; // id for infoWindows State const iWState = {}; iWState[index4] = false; iWFisc[index3] = ( ' + marker.nombre_del_proyecto + '
' + '' + marker.empresa_responsable + '
' + 'Fase: ' + marker.fase + '
' + 'Dimensi√≥n (MW): ' + marker.dimesion + '
' + 'Inicio Planificaci√≥n: ' + marker.fecha_inicio_planemiento + '
' + 'Fin Factibilidad y Evaluaci√≥n: ' + marker.fecha_fin_fact_eval + '
' + 'Gasto Preinversi√≥n (millones de colones): ' + marker.gasto_preinv_millones_col + '
' + 'Inspecci√≥n ARESEP: I-Cuatr 2018 (Ver Informe).

' + 'Descripci√≥n: ' + marker.justificacion + '

' } onCloseClick={evt => { if (!iWState[index4]) { iWState[index4] = true; obj1.iWVisibleFisc[index4] = iWState[index4]; obj1.iWsFisc[index3] = iWFisc[index3]; this.forceUpdate(); } else { iWState[index4] = false; obj1.iWVisibleFisc[index4] = iWState[index4]; obj1.iWsFisc[index3] = false; this.forceUpdate(); } }} /> ); markerFisc[index2] = ( { [Truncated] iWState[index4] = false; obj1.iWVisibleFisc[index4] = iWState[index4]; obj1.iWsFisc[index3] = false; this.forceUpdate(); } }} /> ); Object.assign(obj1.markersFisc, markerFisc); // obj1.markersFisc[index2] = markerFisc[index2]; // put markers under its own root obj1.iWsFisc[index3] = iWState[index4]; // small trick, under IW put all false, then on clicks, update them accordingly obj1.iWVisibleFisc[index4] = iWState[index4]; // IW state } }); this.setState(prevState => { return { obj1 }; }); // state set: newly created obj console.log('----------'); } ``` username_1: Wow, this is really complex. Why isn't this logic in the render function? username_3: Yes, it is complex. so sorry. The reason for this complexity is because the React Google Map wrapper is coded in a way to accept React components as children and render them, i.e.: ` _{/* this is a marker for a location */}_ _{/* this is a marker for another location */}_ _{/* and so on, and so forth */}_ ` According to the Dropdown values, the markers will be mounted/unmounted to the map (via react children components). And, inside each rendered marker, I have set an `onClick` prop for showing/hiding those rendered markers' infowindows individually (hence, the `forceUpdate()`). I guesss I should take this last logic out of the `onClick` props and render them in a different way, although still atached to each rendered markers, mmm... username_1: Are you familiar with [React data flow](https://reactjs.org/docs/thinking-in-react.html) in general? Typically instead of manually managing a list of children like this, your render method should have something like ```js let markers = []; // fill these markers based on state // ... // and then render them return {markers} ``` username_3: Actually yes, I am using that in my render. Particularly, upon deciding what markers to render (due to the Dropdowns), I create small containers, i.e.: `const objMarkersElecCont = Object.values(this.state.obj1.markersElec);` then, I let React conditionally render (because there may be markers or not on-screen), i.e.: `{Array.isArray(objMarkersElecCont) ? objMarkersElecCont : false}` username_1: I'd just suggest not putting React elements into state. I think this would make the code clearer.

Based on a bug found in UFI2.

There have been several bugs related to the update queue (and specifically baseState) recently, so I'm going to follow-up with some refactoring to clean it up. This is a quick fix so we can ship a patch release.

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: TSAN issue in autograd "set_next_edges"
username_0: ## üêõ Bug

Complete TSAN trace: https://gist.github.com/username_0/2bc7e2e44e0a32e51fdad30d21357e7f

## To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Run `test_trainer_ps_sparse` from `test_tensorpipe_agent.py` with TSAN.
<issue_comment>username_0: The issue seems to be coming from multiple autograd nodes having an edge to the same grad_accumulator and calling `set_next_edges` concurrently. If I remove this logic to reuse the grad_accumulator: https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/blob/master/torch/csrc/autograd/variable.cpp#L209 and always create a new grad_accumulator, it seems to fix the TSAN issue.
<issue_comment>username_1: Thanks for the report.
The `set_next_edges` is called on the Node that each thread creates so why would that race? The AccumulateGrad Node doesn't have its next edges set.

Also does this repro without the distributed autograd engine being involved?
<issue_comment>username_0: Distributed autograd engine is not involved since this is still the forward pass. The multithreaded behavior comes from the fact that multiple RPCs are using the same tensor.
<issue_comment>username_2: Most likely it is the same issue as https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/58442, and this is expected.
<issue_comment>username_0: Could you clarify why this is expected behavior? It seems really fragile that using a Tensor with `requires_grad=True` from multiple threads can cause inconsistencies in the autograd graph even if the user is only reading from the Tensor.
<issue_comment>username_2: There are two potential races related to topological_nr that I think TSAN could be complaining about, but both should be non-issues:
1. There is a potential write-write race where two nodes A, B in two threads try to set their next edge to the same node C. This leads to both threads trying to write the `_has_parent` field of C at the same time. There is no correctness issues here though because they are both writing the same value `true`. 

2. There is another write-read race. When a node calls set_next_edges, as to enforce the invariant of topological numbers it will first verify that if its own `_has_parent` is not `true`. In theory there is a race where this node's own `_has_parent` field is being set in one thread (because another node is calling set_next_edge to it), and this node is calling set_next_edges on a separate thread. If this happens, it can lead to correctness issues, but in practice whenever we construct a new node we always call set_next_edges right afterwards, so no other thread should have access to the node at that time.
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_2 I see, so can we probably make `_has_parent` atomic with memory_order_relaxed so that TSAN doesn't complain about this?
<issue_comment>username_1: What would be the perf implication of this change?
<issue_comment>username_3: Just slapping memory_order_relaxed doesn't mean TSAN won't complain about it (c.f. https://github.com/google/sanitizers/issues/1009 ). An atomic with the correct memory order, however, is the right fix, and should give you the same x86 instructions in the end (no perf hit).
<issue_comment>username_1: Good point! https://godbolt.org/z/WEY79csKf
We should change that then.

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: WIP Improve error message thrown in Fiber with multiple copies of React
username_0: **what is the change?:**
Adding an 'invariant' with detailed error message for the problem that
occurs when you load two copies of React with the Fiber reconciler.

WIP:
 - Is there any other likely cause for this error besides two copies of
   React?
 - How can we make the message more clear?

Still TODO:
 - Write a unit test
 - Write a documentation page and create the link to the page, similar
   to https://facebook.github.io/react/warnings/refs-must-have-owner.html

It would also be nice to have a page with instructions on how to fix
common cases of accidental double-loading of React, but we can open a
separate issue on that and let the community do it.

**why make this change?:**
This error comes up relatively often and we want to make things clear
when it happens in v16.0+

**test plan:**
WIP

**issue:**
Fixes #9962 
Related to #8854
<issue_comment>username_1: Would this invariant make more sense as an `else` to this `if`?

https://github.com/facebook/react/blob/2e2f503cb84842d588295d8283366793bff1c8eb/src/renderers/shared/fiber/ReactChildFiber.js#L124

That way only that one piece of code needs to care about string refs.
<issue_comment>username_0: I think that makes sense @username_1 - if we put the 'invariant' there then we could even use basically the same error message and doc page, right?
<issue_comment>username_1: Yeah.

I would tweak it a bit: "Expected ref to be a function" is a little confusing if you pass a string ref because it requires the reader to understand that React converts the string to a function behind the scenes, which is an implementation detail. Something like "Element ref was specified as a string (myRef) but no owner was set." could be better. In the case that it's neither string nor function, you could say "Expected ref to be a function or a string".
<issue_comment>username_2: Maybe also let's not include `commitAttachRef(...)` there? It's not very useful to us since there's only one such invariant, and it's confusing to the user since it shows an internal method name as if they were expected to know what it means,
<issue_comment>username_0: Ah - I meant we could reuse the warning wording and docs from the old warning that gets thrown in 15.* - https://facebook.github.io/react/warnings/refs-must-have-owner.html

But I think you are right, we should give a specific error for this case, and probably a new docs page similar to https://facebook.github.io/react/warnings/refs-must-have-owner.html

I spent a while trying to write a test for this, and wasn't able to reproduce the error in the test environment. I was trying to use '[jestResetModules](https://facebook.github.io/jest/docs/jest-object.html#jestresetmodules)' to load and use a second copy of React, and it seemed to work, but the error wasn't triggered.

This is what I tried: https://gist.github.com/username_0/46f744f6981f1f35861ef4cdeba67af1

Since we didn't have a test for the old warning (Refs must have owner) we could merge this without a test.

Writing a fixture that reproduces the error seems easier, but I don't want to commit to the overhead of checking it manually.
<issue_comment>username_0: I can't find any way to trigger the case where 'In the case that it's neither string nor function, you could say "Expected ref to be a function or a string".' so I'm not putting too much thought into that message, but I guess it makes sense to add that invariant since we *do* expect it to be a string or a function.
<issue_comment>username_1: What happens if you do ref={17} or ref={{abc: true}}?
<issue_comment>username_0: It doesn't complain for `ref={17}`, `ref={{abc: true}}`. The only thing I found to pass to `ref` that throws is `ref={Function}` and I think that is bad syntax, not really worried about someone doing that.
<issue_comment>username_0: And now it has a test! Thank youuuuuu @username_2 üèéÔ∏è
<issue_comment>username_0: I thought it would be more clear that way - looking now for patterns that are used currently.
<issue_comment>username_0: I'll update it to all be in one `it(...` assertion.
<issue_comment>username_1: I guess I am confused why there needs to be a branch at all. Is the behavior not the same?
<issue_comment>username_0: For the record, we talked more about why there needs to be a different branch for 'fiber' and 'stack' versions of this behavior; the new warning is in fiber only, and the old warning shows up if you are using stack.

The old warning will go away when we delete stack, but for now the test is covering both cases.

source.context:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Clarify lifecycle (renderComponent vs. renderComponentToString)
username_0: As discussed on IRC, the lifecycle functions are misleading when using `renderComponentToString`. Namely, because `componentWillMount` is called, but `componentDidMount` is not.

At the least, this should be documented on the lifecycle docs page. There was also discussion about changing the method names. (Note: there's clearly a need for both hooks; the only issue is that name of the former conveys that the component will mount when, in fact, it won't.)

One possibility is to add another always-run phase before the mounting phase which is run when rendered to string or DOM (e.g. "prepare" or "initialize"). The lifecycle would then be easily explained as follows:

1. Prepare the compoent
2. Mount the component (if rendering to DOM)
3. Render the component for the first time.

I'd be happy to contribute a PR for either docs, method names, or both once a decision is reached.
<issue_comment>username_1: We do want to support async server rendering, but I'm going to close this issue out as the original docs it asked for are done now and I think we have other issues open to track async server rendering.<issue_closed>

question.chain_of_thought: The answer explains that the suggested addition is to implement 'torch.eye_like' to create an nXn matrix with the same number of samples in batch as another given tensor. It also highlights the motivation behind this proposal, which is to standardize the creation of eye matrices by preserving the same batch, type, and device as the input tensor.
question.question: What is the suggested addition to PyTorch's functionality related to 'torch.eye' and why is it proposed?
question.answer: The suggested addition is to implement 'torch.eye_like' that creates an nXn matrix with the same number of samples in batch as another given tensor. It is proposed to unify the creation of eye matrices by maintaining the same batch, type, and device as the input tensor.

source.context:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: eyes_like
username_0: ## üöÄ Feature
`torch.eye` only returns a nXn matrix with no batch dim. I suggest adding `torch.eye_like` that will create a nXn matrix with same number of samples in batch as another tensor.

## Motivation

eye matrices is widely used in various fields, and creating this short alias can unify its creation, by keeping the same batch, type and device as the given tensor.

## Additional context

`def eyes_like(x: torch.Tensor, n: int) -> torch.Tensor:
    """
    Return a tensor with same batch size as x, that has a nxn eye matrix in each sample in batch.

    Args:
        x: tensor of shape (B, *).

    Returns:
        tensor of shape (B, n, n) that has the same dtype and device as x.
    """
    return torch.eye(n, n, dtype=x.dtype, device=x.device).unsqueeze(0).repeat(x.shape[0], 1, 1)`
<issue_comment>username_1: Related closed one: https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/9244, but I still think that eye_like will be useful, and if needed can select the dims if not wanting the last two dimension, multidim functions are common now
<issue_comment>username_2: Triage review to discuss whether we still don't want to implement this.
<issue_comment>username_3: @mruberry we should extend `eye` constructor to support batch matrix creation

## üöÄ Feature
`torch.eye` only returns a nXn matrix with no batch dim. I suggest adding `torch.eye_like` that will create a nXn matrix with same number of samples in batch as another tensor.

## Motivation

eye matrices is widely used in various fields, and creating this short alias can unify its creation, by keeping the same batch, type and device as the given tensor.

## Additional context

`def eyes_like(x: torch.Tensor, n: int) -> torch.Tensor:
    """
    Return a tensor with same batch size as x, that has a nxn eye matrix in each sample in batch.

    Args:
        x: tensor of shape (B, *).

    Returns:
        tensor of shape (B, n, n) that has the same dtype and device as x.
    """
    return torch.eye(n, n, dtype=x.dtype, device=x.device).unsqueeze(0).repeat(x.shape[0], 1, 1)`

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: [PyTorch, Mobile] Serialization format change for source range
username_0: Stack from [ghstack](https://github.com/ezyang/ghstack):
* **#54284 [PyTorch, Mobile] Serialization format change for source range**

Summary:
In order to bring mobile deployment, via lite interpreter, on feature
parity with JIT, with respect model level debug information we must make
model level debug information available to mobile runtime.
At the moment, model level debug information is stored in SourceRange
which associates node's of graph to where the come from in original
python source code.
This information is serialized as part of debug_pkl and deserialized
when JIT loads the model and reads the model code.
On lite interpreter, we do not have access to all the functionality of
JIT and hence we cannot load model in the same way as JIT, by reading
code, constructing module hierarchy and graph corresponding module
methods etc. Instead in, lite interpreter, only bytecode corresonding to
the compiled graph, Code, is saved.
Thus in order to annotate OPs in the bytecode with equivalent
SourceRange information we do the following:
1. During model serialization, we create a unique tag for each source
range of the model.
2. Create a map of <SourceRange, tag>
3. During debug_pkl serialization we save tag along with SourceRange, on
top of byte offset.
4. During bytecode generation, the methods of the top module are
lowered. During this process methods are inlined. In the inlined graph,
when the node of a graph is lowered to bytecode, we query node's source
range and look it up against the map.
5. Resulting source range tag is serialized in module_debug_info.
6. During model deserialization, we read all the debug_pkl records in
the archieve and create a map of <tag, SourceRange>
7. This map can be used to find source code information.

During mobile runtime:
1. We read all the debug_pkl records and create <tag=debug_handle,
SourceRange> map.
   1.1 This map, MobileDebugInfo, is a member of mobile Module.
2. Interpreter catches appropriate exceptions and sets the thread local
debug handle and rethrows the exception.
3. In Function's run method we catch exception and query current debug
handle where the exception happened.
4. Query MobileDebugInfo with debug handle to retrieve source range and
augment error with source range info.

This information is still incomplete as it does not contain entire
callstack.

In the following diffs we will serialize InlinedCallStack directly.

Note that compilation is gated by SYMBOLICATE_MOBILE_DEBUG_HANDLE macro,
so that mobile builds can avoid building MobileDebugInfo, source range
and source range pickler/unpickler. Later we will add path where, if
building without debug support stack trace will contain only debug
handles. They can be symbolicated later.

Test Plan:
Ported bunch of source range tests from test_jit.py. Added on more test
in test_lite_interpreter.py

Reviewers:

Subscribers:

Tasks:

Tags:
<issue_comment>username_1: Thanks @username_0 

Your description makes sense, but just to summarize our and clarify a few items.

**Serialize data**
The debug information for lite interpreter will consist of 3 artifacts:
1. <SourceRange, Tag> map, where:
1.a SourceRange - associates a node's of the computation graph to its location in the original python source code.
1.b Tag - uniquely identifies the SourceRange (maybe ID would have been a better name?)
1.c This is stored in debug_pkl.
1.d This data (debug_pkl) is optional to include in model or not.
1.e This is loaded in the lite interpreter to recreate the inverse map.

2. Each statement will have the unique Tag associated to it and serialized with it, corresponding to its SourceRange.
2. a Since the Tag is always going to be added (correct?), efficiency matters (numeric, int32 sounds good).

3. Call stack data.
3.a Not part of this diff.
3.b Also meant to be optional to include in model or not.

**Runtime behavior**
1. debug_pkl gets deserialized to produce a map <Tag, SourceRange> (aka MobileDebugInfo)
2. On exception we obtain the Tag associated with the failing statement, look for its SourceRange and add it to the exception data (and in the future will add call stack info as well). 

**Questions / notes:**
1.a  Question: "node of the computation graph" maps to a statement in bytecode, correct? If not we should clarify, but meanwhile I'll just refer to "node" as "statement" since we serialize bytecode not the graph per se.

1.c The mapping to a Tag being new, introduced in this PR.

1.e Perhaps silly question, are we really storing them in inverse form?

2. In the future, do we plan to use a new exception type?


Thanks

I'm going through the code in more detail.
<issue_comment>username_0: Yes. The next step after this PR is: 1. Serialize inlined call stack ptr and use that directly 2. Move to new exception type.
<issue_comment>username_2: Adding @eellison  as reviewer, who is knowledgable about the serialization format.
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_1 so here I think we will break BC as blast radius seems small. I dont think this is being used very much, internally at least. For longer term we may have to figure out versioning on debug info serialization.
<issue_comment>username_0: @dreiss I had not considered that. But compiled source code is what gets saved in the code files for TS models. So in theory having tuple(byte_offset, source_range_tag, source range), in .debug_pkl, should also allow us to build a map of source_range_tag-to-byte-offset. This can then give us the byte offset in the transformed/compiled code.  Is that what you meant?
<issue_comment>username_1: @dreiss 
"I think having a sentinel value is valuable."
Having a sentinel value for a field that's always meant to be present, except for old models that do not have debug handles seems could be achieved in a cleaner way (particularly if we're going as far as using 64b for the field); but since right now we don't do model level decision based on this field I don't feel strongly about it.

Actually, my main question @username_0 is whether we see a case where debug handles may have valid values along with -1 in them. Then I completely agree a flag (sentinel) at the instruction level is necessary.
<issue_comment>username_0: So at the moment, I dont see a usecase where have -1 as debug handle. David brought up a point about why top level module's type name had to be passed in for symbolication. Can that not be serialized as well? And I was thinking, as I said in my comment, whether we can use some special debug handle that contain top level class's type name.
Besides that nothing else comes to mind immediately.

question.chain_of_thought: The answer summarizes the enhancements made to PyTorch based on the details provided in the text chunk.
question.question: What enhancements are made to PyTorch regarding sparse tensor operations and autograd support based on the provided text chunk?
question.answer: The enhancements include the addition of `sparse.max()` and `sparse.min()` functions for single dimension or global reduction on SparseTensor, autograd support with the strategy of storing reduce_from indices and scattering grad values during backward propagation, and the introduction of `coalesce_max` and `coalesce_min` functions for coalesce reductions.

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: [sparse] sparse.max(), sparse.min()
username_0: - add `sparse.max()` and `sparse.min()` that supports single dim / global reduction on SparseTensor. In single dim reduction, unlike `torch.max()` and `torch.min()` that will return a tuple of `(max, max_indices)`, here only returns a `max` or `min`
- add autograd support, here the strategy is to store reduce_from indices, and during the backward, scatter grad values to grad-of-input according to indices
- add other two coalesce reductions: `coalesce_max` and `coalesce_min`

question.chain_of_thought: The reason for avoiding a regular finalizer and the introduction of `weakref.finalize` as a better alternative is highlighted in the text, leading to the explanation provided in the answer.
question.question: Why is a regular finalizer avoided in the implementation of `_PeriodicTimer`?
question.answer: A regular finalizer is avoided in the implementation of `_PeriodicTimer` to prevent deadlocks that can occur when joining a daemon thread during the interpreter shutdown. Instead, the `weakref.finalize` is considered a superior alternative due to its consistent behavior regardless of the GC implementation.

username_0: Stack from [ghstack](https://github.com/ezyang/ghstack):

This PR fixes a subtle issue with the finalizer implementation of `_PeriodicTimer`.

We avoid using a regular finalizer (a.k.a. `__del__`) for stopping the timer as joining a daemon thread during the interpreter shutdown can cause deadlocks. The `weakref.finalize` is a superior alternative that provides a consistent behavior regardless of the GC implementation.

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: [PyTorch Mobile] Skip generating code for BoxedKernelWrapper when building or mobile
username_0: Stack from [ghstack](https://github.com/username_2/ghstack):
* **#49367 [PyTorch Mobile] Skip generating code for BoxedKernelWrapper when building or mobile**

When building for mobile, we don't need BoxedKernelWrapper since it's used to call boxed implementations of functions with from an unboxed call context (i.e. the wrapper converts an unboxed call into a call to a boxed operator implementation, and then unboxes the return value to pass on to the original caller). This is done using template expansion since the types are all known at build time.

This results in generated code that is practically unused.

Differential Revision: [D25521462](https://our.internmc.facebook.com/intern/diff/D25521462/)
<issue_comment>username_1: This might work right now but will break when we start using backend fallbacks for things. Not sure if we should land this. We're considering backend fallbacks for some things that are relevant for mobile too, say Variable kernels.

The savings are in the range of 37KiB-59KiB depending which app you look at, so not life changing, but we are entering the stage of long tail of small size improvements (@username_2 's note about efficiency resonates with size work too). They also mentioned the possibility of writing an RFC to address this scenario.
question.question: What code did the user try to use to overwrite batched updates in React?

source.context:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Bug: batched updates can't be disabled
username_0: React version: 16.9.5

## Steps To Reproduce

1. Overwrite batched updates with the following code: `ReactDOM.unstable_batchedUpdates = callback => callback()`
2. Batched updates aren't actually overwritten.

## Reasoning

I recognize that this may not be classified as bug because it isn't a documented feature but I have tried to search for a different solution but to no avail. Fixing this behavior can open a new way of using React. I tried writing on [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/60852219/disable-unstable-batchedupdates-on-event-handlers-in-react) and writing to [@username_1](https://twitter.com/antoniostoilkov/status/1242789762307588097).

I have a number of arguments which support the disabling of batched updates in event handlers and in effects initialization. If anybody is willing to read a document and consider this scenario I am willing to write an RFC.
<issue_comment>username_0: I started wondering if [RFCs for changes to React](https://github.com/reactjs/rfcs) isn't a better place to write this issue. Let me know if you agree and I will close this one and write one there.
<issue_comment>username_1: If anything, we are going to _batch more_ by default, not batch less. Batching is important for multiple reasons, including drastically improving performance for bubbling events, and to avoid inconsistent trees.

If you need to make a specific call unbatched, you can do this manually:

```js
ReactDOM.flushSync(() => {
  // this setState won't be batched
  setState(something)
})
```<issue_closed>
<issue_comment>username_0: Is there a way to apply `flushSync()` to every event handler? I can provide a custom `useLayoutEffect()` and `useEffect()` functions but it is harder with event handlers.

We constantly observe bugs caused by the same code behaving differently in two places because at one place batching is happening and at the other, it isn't. I am not saying disabling batching by default, I believe in general this is better for most projects but I can clearly see that in our project it is introducing bugs for the past year. This is strange because our software is almost bug-free. However, batching is probably our biggest contributor to bugs right now.
<issue_comment>username_1: This is interesting. This behavior has been there for over five years, and this is the first time I'm hearing this worded so strongly. (Usually people learn about batching once, learn not to read from `this.state`, and call it a day.) So I'm curious if there are particular patterns that cause this to be an issue for you.

If it's the inconsistency that gets you, you could apply `batchedUpdates` in more places instead. In a future version of React, this will be the default behavior for everything so the inconsistency will go away.
<issue_comment>username_1: I guess if you really want to do it, maybe something like this could work:

```js
const origSetState = React.Component.prototype.setState
React.Component.prototype.setState = function(...args) {
  ReactDOM.flushSync(() => {
    origSetState.apply(this, arguments);
  })
}
```

and you can probably come up with something similar for Hooks (or use your own `useState` Hook).

Needless to say, this is terrible for performance and will cause issues both for third-party components and for the future you who will be debugging this.
<issue_comment>username_0: I am currently writing an example to show you the cases we are hitting and why bugs are appearing. Will get back to you soon.
<issue_comment>username_0: Here is the example: https://codesandbox.io/s/cranky-sanderson-7kdcx.

Now let me explain:
1) Clicking "Log in" throws an error showing the bug.
1) I know that this example can be fixed by adding `autoFocus` to the input. However, imagine that focusing is conditional and the component doesn't know if it should focus itself when being created. If the new component should be focused is determined from the place that triggers the new component to show so no way to know in the component itself. Adding if the component should be focused as a state property introduces a new set of problems that I can explain if you want.
1) The same happens with any method of the element like `scrollIntoView()` or `getBoundingClientRect()`. For us `focus()` and `scrollIntoView()` are the most common. Mainly `focus()`.
1) I understand this is a domain-specific problem because our application is shortcut-heavy and manages focus very strictly. I can even show you the app and give you 4-5 bugs that were caused by that behavior.

The main problem is that `inputRef.current` in the `onClick()` handler will have a different value depending on batched updates being used or not.

Note that if you can't understand what are the use cases of having access to a ref after updating the state I can go into bigger details and real-world use cases in our app.

I hope that you understood me. Let me emphasize that our app manages focus a lot and React isn't good at handling focus. Maybe if a good solution for focusing exists this kind of problems can be fixed with an abstraction and not by disabling batched updates but until then I have tried many things and haven't found a solution.
<issue_comment>username_0: By the way, using `flushSync()` we can do something else and avoid disabling batched updates directly. We have methods that change the state and we can wrap all of them with `flushSync()`. I am describing everything above in order to help you understand a set of use cases that I believe are valid. I hope I will be helpful because for me it is a little strange I didn't found anybody talking about this problem.
<issue_comment>username_1: That's a good callout. It's fair to say React doesn't really give you the tools to do it very well. We've been doing some work in that area but it's behind an experimental flag and is not ready to be a stable API yet. This is definitely something that's on our minds but we won't have a solution in the very near future.

In class-based code, you could do this to work around the problem:

```js
setState({ isVisible: true }, () => {
  this.inputRef.curent.focus()
})
```

That's the idiomatic workaround in classes. We don't (yet?) have something similar exposed for Hooks because that exact API won't work. In particular, it would "see" old props and state which would be highly confusing.

Currently, in function components the only way you can get "notified" about commits is with `useLayoutEffect`. Here is an example:

```js
  useLayoutEffect(() => {
    if (isTwoFactorAuthenticationVisible) {
      inputRef.current.focus();
    }
  }, [isTwoFactorAuthenticationVisible]);
```

That would solve your problem: https://codesandbox.io/s/laughing-fast-9785u.

However, I agree this solution isn't ideal because the desire to focus might in some cases have more to do with *which action triggered it* rather than *which state changed*.

I think there are at least two opportunities for RFC design here:

- More intuitive and declarative focus management that works within the React paradigm. (There was some work on this here: https://github.com/reactjs/rfcs/pull/109, although I don't think this necessarily addresses your concerns. Maybe you could comment on it.)
- A way to express "run some side effect after a particular setState is flushed". We have this for classes, but not for Hooks. It seems like a useful feature. But it's not clear what the design should be like. So working on that would also be beneficial.

I don't think the solution is to "revert back" to a paradigm where each setState is atomic. We think this would be a regression. Instead, we think this needs to be "fixed forward" by finding the right abstractions that work with the React model. In the meantime, I hope the workarounds above are reasonable.

```js
  const perform = useCommand(command => {
    if (command === "focusInput") {
      inputRef.current.focus();
    }
  });

  // ...

  setState(...)
  perform("focusInput');
```

https://codesandbox.io/s/blissful-elgamal-umn3p

In this example, `useCommand` maintains an internal queue of commands to run at the commit time. You can schedule more of them by calling `perform` returned to it. The commands are guaranteed to run in the commit phase and each runs only once.

<issue_comment>username_1: We chatted about this with @sebmarkbage and he noticed these examples tend to be similar to our internal notion of ‚Äúupdate queues‚Äù. So maybe that‚Äôs something we could expose as a lower level concept.

It seems like they often have a particular thing in common: you want ‚Äúthe last one to win‚Äù. For example:

* If multiple things call focus, you want only the last one to win.

* If multiple things call scrollIntoView, you want the last one to win.

However these queues are separate. You don‚Äôt want scrollIntoView to ‚Äúoverwrite‚Äù the focus operation.

Note that declarative attributes like autoFocus suffers from a flaw where instead of the last operation winning, we have the last sibling winning. That doesn‚Äôt really make sense. It‚Äôs the last operation that matters.

We were thinking there could be:

```js 
import { queueFocus } from ‚Äòreact-dom'

const onClick = () => {
  queueFocus(inputRef)
  setState()
})
```

Note we‚Äôre passing the *ref itself*. So it doesn‚Äôt matter that React hasn‚Äôt set it yet. It will read from mutable object when the time comes. 

If it‚Äôs a more generic concept that‚Äôs not limited to focus then it could get more powerful. But also more verbose.

```js
// singleton
export const useScrollQueue = createEffectQueue()
export const useFocusQueue = createEffectQueue()

// app
import { useFocusQueue } from 'somewhere'

// ...
const queueFocus = useFocusQueue()

const onClick = () => {
  queueFocus(inputRef)
  setState()
})
```

Although then the question becomes where do we keep those queues and how to get third party components to agree on using them. So perhaps they should be built-in after all.

This is why we want to understand the full breadth of the use cases. Are they all ‚Äúfire and forget‚Äù, are they all ‚Äúlast one wins‚Äù, and how many common distinct ones there are.

Maybe this could be an RFC.
<issue_comment>username_1: With focus specifically @trueadm said there‚Äôs even more pitfalls. That there are cases to consider about blur event handlers causing other focus, or focus causing other focus. Cascading effects. And that sometimes the browser needs to paint first. I don‚Äôt have all the background knowledge to talk about this but it‚Äôs something you would need to research if you plan to write an RFC.

```typescript
import { useMemo, MutableRefObject, useRef, useCallback } from 'react'
import useForceUpdate from 'use-force-update'

export default function useElementRef<T extends HTMLElement | null>(): MutableRefObject<T> & {
  queueFocus(): void
  queueScrollIntoView(arg?: boolean | ScrollIntoViewOptions | undefined): void
} {
  const nextLayoutEffect = useNextLayoutEffect()
  const value = useMemo(() => {
    const callback: MutableRefObject<T> & {
      queueFocus(): void
      queueScrollIntoView(arg?: boolean | ScrollIntoViewOptions | undefined): void
    } = (element: T): void => {
      callback.current = element
    }
    callback.current = null!
    callback.queueFocus = (): void => {
      nextLayoutEffect(() => {
        callback.current?.focus()
      })
    }
    callback.queueScrollIntoView = (arg?: boolean | ScrollIntoViewOptions): void => {
      nextLayoutEffect(() => {
        callback.current?.scrollIntoView(arg)
      })
    }

    return callback
  }, [nextLayoutEffect])

  return value
}

function useNextLayoutEffect(): (callback: () => void) => void {
  const callbacks = useRef<(() => void)[]>([])
  const forceUpdate = useForceUpdate()

  return useCallback(
    (callback: () => void) => {
      callbacks.current.push(callback)
      forceUpdate()
    },
    [forceUpdate],
  )
}
```

Usage:
```typescript
const inputRef = useElementRef()

function openTab() {
  // change state

  inputRef.queueFocus()
}
```

<issue_comment>username_0: Ok, I am now able to replicate this problem using just `torch.rand` and `torch.linalg.svd`.

u,s,v = torch.linalg.svd(x)

<issue_comment>username_1: Thank you for the tiny repro! I can reproduce in master. cc @username_2
<issue_comment>username_2: The problem is related to https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/51720.

The optimal workspace size for the input of this size is `2.70021e+09` which doesn't fit into `int` type. In PyTorch, we use a 32-bit interface to backend linear algebra libraries.
We can "fix" the internal assert with this patch
```
diff --git a/aten/src/ATen/native/BatchLinearAlgebra.cpp b/aten/src/ATen/native/BatchLinearAlgebra.cpp
index 853f5c2cbe..8902958d98 100644
--- a/aten/src/ATen/native/BatchLinearAlgebra.cpp
+++ b/aten/src/ATen/native/BatchLinearAlgebra.cpp
@@ -2984,7 +2984,9 @@ static void apply_svd(Tensor& self, Tensor& U, Tensor& S, Tensor& VT,
   int lwork = -1;
   scalar_t wkopt;
   lapackSvd<scalar_t, value_t>(jobz, m, n, self_data, lda, S_data, U_data, lda, VT_data, ldvt, &wkopt, lwork, rwork_data, iwork_data, &info);
-  lwork = std::max<int>(1, real_impl<scalar_t, value_t>(wkopt));
+  TORCH_CHECK(
+      (real_impl<scalar_t, value_t>(wkopt)) < INT_MAX,
+      "svd: The optimal workspace size is larger than allowed by 32-bit interface to backend math library.");
   Tensor work = at::empty({lwork}, self.options());
   auto work_data = work.data_ptr<scalar_t>();
```
The issue is likely there for other functions as well and we could include checks of the values before casting them to int.
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_2 will there be any way around this in the future for large SVDs? Or is there an upper size limit due to the 32bit interface?
<issue_comment>username_2: Unfortunately, there is no workaround available.
From the MKL documentation the workspace size (`lwork`) can be computed using these guidelines:
```
For real flavors:

If jobz = 'N', lwork ‚â• 3*min(m, n) + max (max(m,n), 6*min(m, n));

If jobz = 'O', lwork ‚â• 3*(min(m, n))2 + max (max(m, n), 5*(min(m, n))2 + 4*min(m, n));

If jobz = 'S' or 'A', lwork ‚â• 3*(min(m, n))2 + max (max(m, n), 4*(min(m, n))2 + 4*min(m, n))

For complex flavors:

If jobz = 'N', lwork ‚â• 2*min(m, n) + max(m, n);

If jobz = 'O', lwork ‚â• 2*(min(m, n))2 + max(m, n) + 2*min(m, n);

If jobz = 'S' or 'A', lwork ‚â• (min(m, n))2 + max(m, n) + 2*min(m, n);
```
`lwork` must be smaller than `2147483647` (maximum `int`) in order to not hit the limitation of the 32-bit interface.
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_2 Any clue as to why `svdvals` and `eigvalsh` work?
<issue_comment>username_1: For what is worth, `svdvals` and `eigvalsh` may work in master when the input does not require gradients, as we do not compute the `U` and the `Vh` in those cases, so the working space needed is less than for the full SVD / eigendecomposition.

question.chain_of_thought: The issue seems to be related to the rendering performance of large numbers in the application. Formatting the numbers as strings first appears to alleviate the problem. The render time increases disproportionately as more digits are added to the numbers. The issue is exacerbated when dealing with numbers that are not formatted and have 10 or more digits. The example provided with `{123456789.1234}` is enough to slow down the render process. The problem is not specific to a particular section of the application.
question.question: What potential solution helped alleviate the issue with rendering large numbers in the application?
question.answer: Formatting the numbers as strings first seemed to fix the problem.

source.context: Title: Large number render performance? username_0: I am seeing an issue where large numbers take a long time to render. I almost don't believe it's happening, but there seems to be a worse-than-linear increase in render time as I add digits to numbers. Formatting as string first seems to fix the problem. I tried to build a fiddle to exemplify the issue, but I think it's exacerbated by being pretty far down the DOM tree. Doesn't seem to matter where in the app I do it; if numbers aren't formatted, and get to be 10+ digits, it takes seconds for the render to finish. Let me know if you can't reproduce, and I will try to carve out an example app. Just try setting some component in a "real" app to something like `{123456789.1234}`, this seems to be enough to slow it down for me. username_0: Nevermind. Probably a consequence of #4776.

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Unable to import pytorch
username_0: ## üêõ Bug

<!Upon importing pytorch, I get OsError: [WinError 126].>

## To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Try to import pytorch using "import torch"

## Expected behavior

<!-- Pytorch should be imported without any error-->

## Environment

 - PyTorch Version (e.g., 1.0): 1.6.0
 - OS (e.g., Linux): Windows 10 home 64bit
 - How you installed PyTorch (`conda`, `pip`, source): conda
 - Build command you used (if compiling from source):
 - Python version: 3.8.5
 - CUDA/cuDNN version: Cudatoolkit V10.2.89/cuDNN V7.6.5
 - GPU models and configuration: RTX 2080 TI
 - Any other relevant information:

## Additional context

<!-- There was an error loading asmjit.dll -->
<issue_comment>username_1: @username_0 , did you use `conda install pytorch cudatoolkit=10.2 -c pytorch` to install pytorch
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_1 

I used conda install -c pytorch pytorch and the cuda version that I have was shipped together
<issue_comment>username_2: Could you please post some logs using Process Monitor or the Debugging Tools for Windows?
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_2 How do I do that? I'm not quite sure on how to do that and I haven't been able to find instructions on how to do it.
<issue_comment>username_2: Download process monitor from https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/procmon and open it. And then you just do the normal `import torch` in CMD. Finally, just stop monitoring, save it and post the saved file here.<issue_closed>
<issue_comment>username_0: After running "import torch" in CMD, I found out that the latest Microsoft Visual C++ 2015-2019 Redistributable was not installed on my system. After installing it, I am now able to use pytorch normally. I'll be closing this issue.
<issue_comment>username_2: @username_0 So which environment / IDE are you using previously?
<issue_comment>username_0: I was using Spyder and Spyder failed to mention anything about the lack of Microsoft Visual C++ 2015-2019 Redistributable other than displaying the aforementioned OsError
<issue_comment>username_3: Just adding a comment that this was not an IDE-related issue at all. I too faced the issue when updating to and installing afresh 1.6.0 but with plain old Powershell. And I got the error message despite the fact that the 2017 redistributable was already installed in my computer. Of course, now that I installed 2015-2019 version, things seem to be working normally. If this is a separate requirement that's not installable with conda, would it be possible to add that bit of information to the install instructions?
<issue_comment>username_4: As mentioned earlier, the error can be resolved by installing Microsoft Visual C++ 2015-2019 Redistributable.
<issue_comment>username_5: The error still exists even after installing the latest Microsoft Visual C++ Redistributable... \cry
<issue_comment>username_6: I use "conda install pytorch torchvision torchaudio cpuonly -c pytorch" install pytorchÔºåpython version:3.8.5Ôºåthis error still remain...
<issue_comment>username_1: @username_6 
1. Does the asmjit.dll exist?
2. if asmjit.dll exist, could you please use [depends](https://github.com/lucasg/Dependencies) to see which depends missing?
<issue_comment>username_7: @username_6 can you please share output of `python -mtorch.utils.collect_env` command?
<issue_comment>username_6: Thanks for your reply,I install https://aka.ms/vs/16/release/vc_redist.x64.exe,it works good for me
<issue_comment>username_6: Thanks for your reply,I install https://aka.ms/vs/16/release/vc_redist.x64.exe,it works good for me
